results.title: Moving still
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Uses archival material to show the development of early photography, from the first photograph of 1827 through to the first slow motion study in 1901. Also illustrates how scientists, designers and engineers use time-lapse cameras to cheat time; to look beyond our human perceptions; and to study the world of high and low-speed activity.

results.title: The Mondragon experiment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Mondragon in the Basque region of Spain, is an industrial town where more than 80 factories are co-operatively owned by the workers. All this has been created with scant help from a suspicious government and no funds from stock-market investors. It has run successfully for twenty-five years. The workers run the factories and appoint the managers, run their own bank, technical college and research laboratories. In Britain, workers and management have been at loggerheads since the Industrial Revolution. Examines the feasability of Britain following the same road to prosperity. Narrated by Alexander John

results.title: Mind over body
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A survey of the research done to study how our mental activities affect the development of illness in our lives, and the development of technique by which patients can be taught to use the activity of the mind to produce bodily changes in some of the physiological systems that are most associated with the onset of illness. Also discusses biofeedback - the control of the electrical activity of the brain.

results.title: Migraine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A look at some of the recent research work by scientists in Britain who are attempting to understand and provide treatment for people who suffer from blinding headaches, known as migraines. Shows the problems these sufferers can face in their work and social life.

results.title: Masters of the desert
results.creator_credit: Peter Cantor and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Michael Evenari of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem discovers farming methods used by the Nabatean civilisation in the arid Negev of southern Israel and applies these to the present time for the development of the area.

results.title: The Lost waters of the Nile
results.creator_credit: Alec Nisbett, British Broadcasting Corporation and KRO-TV Hilversum
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Report on the issues surrounding the construction of the Jonglei Canal, a massive engineering project intended to bypass an enormous area of marshland formed by the waters of the White Nile. Considers in particular the effects on the Dinka people who inhabit the area and the difficulties facing the builders of the canal.

results.title: The Life that lives on man
results.creator_credit: Michael Andrews and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Skin, for all its accessibility is one of the least studied organs of the body. Looks at the whole ecology of bacteria, yeasts and animals, which are a human being’s intimate companions through life.

results.title: Let the therapy fit the crime
results.creator_credit: Brian Gibson, Michael Andrews and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
There is a high proportion of persistent offenders in Britain’s gaols. There are two schools of thought concerning the reasons for criminality. Behaviouralists consider that personality is determined by heredity as well as by environment, while psychoanalysts maintain that a criminal’s aggressive behaviour arises out of internal conflict resulting from traumatic experiences in early life. Both schools of thought believe that remedial treatment and not punishment is the only way to help people.

results.title: A Lesson for teacher
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In 1976 Dr Neville Bennett of Lancaster University published his research report evaluating the success and failure of various systems used in British primary schools. This was the first major attempt to analyse scientifically just how much children learn in establishments ranging from the most progressive, open-plan schools, to the most traditional. The publication of the report was an important educational event, and it will give rise to much questioning about the direction of current trends in British education. The report revealed that in one year pupils taught by formal methods can be as much as five months in advance educationally of those taught by the free style.
